ygData.subject: IEX update
ygData.msgSnippet: Here s an update on my Image Enlargement eXperiment (IEX) :) We re up to generation 425.  Still no where near a solution , but proceeding. I found that if I

Here's an update on my Image Enlargement eXperiment (IEX) :)

We're up to generation 425.  Still no where near a 'solution', but 
proceeding.

I found that if I installed cygwin (http://www.redhat.com/software/cygwin/) 
on my windows box, I'm able to use it as a client for the project, too.  So, 
for all those out there that wanted to help, but didn't have a linux box, 
there you go!

Also, Collin, there was a bug in the client that broke the auto-update 
feature.  I fixed it, but you need to manually update your machine in order 
to pick it up.

I've added some nice graphs to the status page.  First graph is maximum 
fitness per generation.  It fluctuates a lot, because of the slightly random 
nature of the fitness evaluation process.  But I've also plotted the running 
average, which definitely shows an upward trend.

The second graph replaces the old HTML-based population fitness graph.  It 
is a bar graph, one bar per network, with the scale of the graph 
representing the range of fitness within the population.  A zero in this 
graph represents the minimum fitness, not a zero fitness.  Likewise, a max 
value does not represent a solution, only the top performer.  The graph only 
shows the relative fitness between networks, not an overall fitness value.  
The graph shows the networks in the order in which they were created, so all 
the elites from the previous generation appear first, followed by the 
offspring for each topology.

The next graph is harder to understand.  It is a measure of how stable, or 
reliable, the fitness value described above is for each network.  If the 
fitness of a network is still wildly fluctuating, then it is not very 
stable.  If the fitness hasn't changed appreciably in some time (where time 
is number of samples processed), then it will have a high stability.  The 
idea is, if we reach a point where all the networks have a stable fitness, 
we are done for that generation (we can finish up early).  Unfortunately, at 
this point there is one topology whose fitness values still fluctuate 
wildly, so it has low stability, so the mechanism that was intended to help 
the experiment get through generations faster isn't yet able to do so.

The final graph is a fitness histogram.  The bars at the extreme left 
represent the lowest fitness within the population, the bars at the right 
represent highest fitness, and the height of the bar represent how many 
networks are in that range of fitness.

The next graph I intend to add is a pie chart, which shows the relative 
investment in each topology (offspring allocation number, not necessarily 
the same thing as actual offspring, since there is an offspring limit).  
I'll try to add that today or tomorrow.

Any comments or suggestions for the status page?  Thanks!

-- John
